Author: Bowers, Alex J.
Title: Analyzing the Longitudinal K-12 Grading Histories of Entire Cohorts of Students: Grades, Data Driven Decision Making, Dropping out and Hierarchical Cluster Analysis
Abstract Note: School personnel currently lack an effective method to pattern and visually interpret disaggregated achievement data collected on students as a means to help inform decision making. This study, through the examination of longitudinal K-12 teacher assigned grading histories for entire cohorts of students from a school district (n=188), demonstrates a novel application of hierarchical cluster analysis and pattern visualization in which all data points collected on every student in a cohort can be patterned, visualized and interpreted to aid in data driven decision making by teachers and administrators. Additionally, as a proof-of-concept study, overall schooling outcomes, such as student dropout or taking a college entrance exam, are identified from the data patterns and compared to past methods of dropout identification as one example of the usefulness of the method. Hierarchical cluster analysis correctly identified over 80% of the students who dropped out using the entire student grade history patterns from either K-12 or K-8. (Contains 5 figures.)
Short Title: Analyzing the Longitudinal K-12 Grading Histories of Entire Cohorts of Students
Automatic Tags: data; data analysis; Decision Making; Dropouts; Elementary School Students; Grades (Scholastic); Identification; MULTIVARIATE analysis; School Districts; Secondary School Students

Author: Grunspan, Daniel Z.; Wiggins, Benjamin L.; Goodreau, Steven M.
Title: Understanding Classrooms through Social Network Analysis: A Primer for Social Network Analysis in Education Research
Abstract Note: Social interactions between students are a major and underexplored part of undergraduate education. Understanding how learning relationships form in undergraduate classrooms, as well as the impacts these relationships have on learning outcomes, can inform educators in unique ways and improve educational reform. Social network analysis (SNA) provides the necessary tool kit for investigating questions involving relational data. We introduce basic concepts in SNA, along with methods for data collection, data processing, and data analysis, using a previously collected example study on an undergraduate biology classroom as a tutorial. We conduct descriptive analyses of the structure of the network of costudying relationships. We explore generative processes that create observed study networks between students and also test for an association between network position and success on exams. We also cover practical issues, such as the unique aspects of human subjects review for network studies. Our aims are to convince readers that using SNA in classroom environments allows rich and informative analyses to take place and to provide some initial tools for doing so, in the process inspiring future educational studies incorporating relational data.
Short Title: Understanding Classrooms through Social Network Analysis

Author: Corbett, Albert T.; Anderson, John R.
Title: Knowledge tracing: Modeling the acquisition of procedural knowledge
Abstract Note: This paper describes an effort to model students' changing knowledge state during skill acquisition. Students in this research are learning to write short programs with the ACT Programming Tutor (APT). APT is constructed around a production rule cognitive model of programming knowledge, called theideal student model. This model allows the tutor to solve exercises along with the student and provide assistance as necessary. As the student works, the tutor also maintains an estimate of the probability that the student has learned each of the rules in the ideal model, in a process calledknowledge tracing. The tutor presents an individualized sequence of exercises to the student based on these probability estimates until the student has ‘mastered’ each rule. The programming tutor, cognitive model and learning and performance assumptions are described. A series of studies is reviewed that examine the empirical validity of knowledge tracing and has led to modifications in the process. Currently the model is quite successful in predicting test performance. Further modifications in the modeling process are discussed that may improve performance levels.
Automatic Tags: Education (general); empirical validity; individual differences; intelligent tutoring systems; Learning; Management of Computing and Information Systems; mastery learning; Multimedia Information Systems; procedural knowledge; Psychology, general; student modeling; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction

Author: Siemens, George; Baker, Ryan S. J. d.
Title: Learning Analytics and Educational Data Mining: Towards Communication and Collaboration
Publication Title: Proceedings of the 2Nd International Conference on Learning Analytics and Knowledge
Abstract Note: Growing interest in data and analytics in education, teaching, and learning raises the priority for increased, high-quality research into the models, methods, technologies, and impact of analytics. Two research communities -- Educational Data Mining (EDM) and Learning Analytics and Knowledge (LAK) have developed separately to address this need. This paper argues for increased and formal communication and collaboration between these communities in order to share research, methods, and tools for data mining and analysis in the service of developing both LAK and EDM fields.
Short Title: Learning Analytics and Educational Data Mining
Notes:
1. EDM and LAK as emerging fields will both benefit from competition and sharing data/ new information. 

2. Both are tackling Learning measurement/ improving learning from different philosophies and tactics.

    a. LAK: from a holistic space looking to improve human judgement

    b. EDM: from an individual lens, looking to incorporate machine learning and automation.
Automatic Tags: Collaboration; educational data mining; learning analytics and knowledge

Author: Baker, Ryan S. J. d; Corbett, Albert T.; Roll, Ido; Koedinger, Kenneth R.
Title: Developing a generalizable detector of when students game the system
Abstract Note: Some students, when working in interactive learning environments, attempt to “game the system”, attempting to succeed in the environment by exploiting properties of the system rather than by learning the material and trying to use that knowledge to answer correctly. In this paper, we present a system that can accurately detect whether a student is gaming the system, within a Cognitive Tutor mathematics curricula. Our detector also distinguishes between two distinct types of gaming which are associated with different learning outcomes. We explore this detector’s generalizability, and find that it transfers successfully to both new students and new tutor lessons.
Automatic Tags: Behavior detection; Cognitive tutors; Education (general); Gaming the system; Generalizable models; Interactive learning environments; Latent response models; Machine learning; Management of Computing and Information Systems; Multimedia Information Systems; student modeling; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction

Author: Greller, Wolfgang; Drachsler, Hendrik
Title: Translating Learning into Numbers: A Generic Framework for Learning Analytics
Abstract Note: ABSTRACT With the increase in available educational data, it is expected that Learning Analytics will become a powerful means to inform and support learners, teachers and their institutions in better understanding and predicting personal learning needs and performance. However, the processes and requirements behind the beneficial application of Learning and Knowledge Analytics as well as the consequences for learning and teaching are still far from being understood. In this paper, we explore the key dimensions of Learning Analytics (LA), the critical problem zones, and some potential dangers to the beneficial exploitation of educational data. We propose and discuss a generic design framework that can act as a useful guide for setting up Learning Analytics services in support of educational practice and learner guidance, in quality assurance, curriculum development, and in improving teacher effectiveness and efficiency. Furthermore, the presented article intends to inform about soft barriers and limitations of Learning Analytics. We identify the required skills and competences that make meaningful use of Learning Analytics data possible to overcome gaps in interpretation literacy among educational stakeholders. We also discuss privacy and ethical issues and suggest ways in which these issues can be addressed through policy guidelines and best practice examples.

Author: Kay, Judy; Maisonneuve, Nicolas; Yacef, Kalina; Reimann, Peter
Title: The Big Five and Visualisations of Team Work Activity
Abstract Note: We have created a set of novel visualisations of group activity: they mirror activity of individuals and their interactions, based upon readily available authentic data. We evaluated these visualisations in the context of a semester long software development project course. We give a theoretical analysis of the design of our visualizations using the framework from the “Big 5” theory of team work as well as a qualitative study of the visualisations and the students’ reflective reports. We conclude that these visualisations provide a powerful and valuable mirroring role with potential, when well used, to help groups learn to improve their effectiveness.
Automatic Tags: Artificial Intelligence (incl. Robotics); Computers and Education; Information Systems Applications (incl. Internet); Multimedia Information Systems; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction

Author: Desmarais, Michel C.; Naceur, Rhouma
Title: A Matrix Factorization Method for Mapping Items to Skills and for Enhancing Expert-Based Q-Matrices
Abstract Note: Uncovering the right skills behind question items is a difficult task. It requires a thorough understanding of the subject matter and of the cognitive factors that determine student performance. The skills definition, and the mapping of item to skills, require the involvement of experts. We investigate means to assist experts for this task by using a data driven, matrix factorization approach. The two mappings of items to skills, the expert on one side and the matrix factorization on the other, are compared in terms of discrepancies, and in terms of their performance when used in a linear model of skills assessment and item outcome prediction. Visual analysis shows a relatively similar pattern between the expert and the factorized mappings, although differences arise. The prediction comparison shows the factorization approach performs slightly better than the original expert Q-matrix, giving supporting evidence to the belief that the factorization mapping is valid. Implications for the use of the factorization to design better item to skills mapping are discussed.
Automatic Tags: alternating least squares matrix factorization; Artificial Intelligence (incl. Robotics); Cognitive modeling; Computers and Education; Educational Technology; Information Systems Applications (incl. Internet); latent skills; Pedagogic Psychology; skills assessment; Student models; User Interfaces and Human Computer Interaction
Editor: Lane, H. Chad; Yacef, Kalina; Mostow, Jack; Pavlik, Philip

Author: Matsuda, Noboru; Furukawa, Tadanobu; Bier, Norman; Faloutsos, Christos
Title: Machine Beats Experts: Automatic Discovery of Skill Models for Data-Driven Online Course Refinement
Abstract Note: How can we automatically determine which skills must be mastered for the successful completion of an online course? Large-scale online courses (e.g., MOOCs) often contain a broad range of contents frequently intended to be a semester's worth of materials; this breadth often makes it difficult to articulate an accurate set of skills and knowledge (i.e., a skill model, or the QMatrix). We have developed an innovative method to discover skill models from the data of online courses. Our method assumes that online courses have a pre-defined skill map for which skills are associated with formative assessment items embedded throughout the online course. Our method carefully exploits correlations between various parts of student performance, as well as in the text of assessment items, to build a superior statistical model that even outperforms human experts. To evaluate our method, we compare our method with existing methods (LFA) and human engineered skill models on three Open Learning Initiative (OLI) courses at Carnegie Mellon University. The results show that (1) our method outperforms human-engineered skill models, (2) skill models discovered by our method are interpretable, and (3) our method is remarkably faster than existing methods. These results suggest that our method provides a significant contribution to the evidence-based, iterative refinement of online courses with a promising scalability. [For complete proceedings, see ED560503.]
Automatic Tags: Automation; Comparative Analysis; Correlation; data; Formative Evaluation; models; Online Courses; Skills

Author: Cortez, Paulo; Silva, Alice Maria Gonçalves
Title: Using data mining to predict secondary school student performance
Publication Title: Proceedings of 5th Annual Future Business Technology Conference
Abstract Note: Although the educational level of the Portuguese population has improved in the last decades, the statistics keep Portugal at Europe’s tail end due to its high student failure rates. In particular, lack of success in the core classes of Mathematics and the Portuguese language is extremely serious. On the other hand, the fields of Business Intelligence (BI)/Data Mining (DM), which aim at extracting high-level knowledge from raw data, offer interesting automated tools that can aid the education domain. The present work intends to approach student achievement in secondary education using BI/DM techniques. Recent real-world data (e.g. student grades, demographic, social and school related features) was collected by using school reports and questionnaires. The two core classes (i.e. Mathematics and Portuguese) were modeled under binary/five-level classification and regression tasks. Also, four DM models (i.e. Decision Trees, Random Forest, Neural Networks and Support Vector Machines) and three input selections (e.g. with and without previous grades) were tested. The results show that a good predictive accuracy can be achieved, provided that the first and/or second school period grades are available. Although student achievement is highly influenced by past evaluations, an explanatory analysis has shown that there are also other relevant features (e.g. number of absences, parent’s job and education, alcohol consumption). As a direct outcome of this research, more efficient student prediction tools can be be developed, improving the quality of education and enhancing school resource management.

Author: Etlinger, Susan
Title: What do we do with all this big data?
Abstract Note: Does a set of data make you feel more comfortable? More successful? Then your interpretation of it is likely wrong. In a surprisingly moving talk, Susan Etlinger explains why, as we receive more and more data, we need to deepen our critical thinking skills. Because it's hard to move beyond counting things to really understanding them.
Notes:
Key Lesson:  We need to focus on our critical thinking skills more with Big data or we'll miss

Facts are stupid things: When assessment and analytics over value one metric and ignores others.  In doing so we limit or frame of reference.

Facts are vulnerable: 

Be clear about our hypothesis

Be confident in the results

"show our work" to account for the things we miss.

Asking tough question: Did the data really show us this or does the result make us feel more successful and comfortable in our bias?

Author: Video, Nature
Title: Is There a Reproducibility Crisis in Science?
Abstract Note: Nature asked 1,576 scientists for their thoughts on reproducibility. Most agree that there's a 'crisis' and over 70% said they'd tried and failed to reproduce another group's experiments.   This video was reproduced with permission and was first published on May 25, 2016. It is a  Nature Video  production.
Notes:
Key Lesson: There may not be an issue with reproducibility in academic study the issue lie more with the cherry picking of data to find particular outcome (bias).

  • 70% try and fail to reproduce another groups experiment
  • >50% failed to reproduce their own work.

Other Reasons for failure may include slight differences in how the project is conducted (Ex. stirring vs shaking a sample)

How to Counter the key challenge:

  1. Better mentorship
  2. More robust experimental design
  3. Proper use of statistics

Author: Meta-Research Innovation Center at Stanford
Title: Session I: Data Transparency and Open Science- Victoria Stodden
Abstract Note: The inaugural conference of the Meta-Research Innovation Center at Stanford (METRICS) took place on November 19-20, 2015 at the Frances C. Arrillaga Alumni Center, Stanford, CA. This highly interactive, evidence-to-action event sought to generate and discuss new ideas about how to improve the way biomedical scientists plan, conduct and communicate research. Help us re-imagine science for the 21st century. Learn more at http://metrics.stanford.edu/  Victoria Stodden, Associate Professor, Graduate School of Library and Information Science, The iSchool at Illinois - Reproducibility in computational science
Notes:
The challenge of reproducibility.

Types of Reproducibility:

  1. Empirical: Traditional scientific method:
    • Branch 1 (deductive): mathematics, formal logic
    • Branch 2 (empirical): statistical analysis of controlled experiments.
    • Challenges of this method:
      • Devil in the details (article): Finding out that one lab was stirring while the other was using a centrifuge to conduct the same experiment, leading to different results
        •    Tacit Knowledge leads to different outcomes
      • What to do when Animals are involved?
    •  
  1. Computational: Use of computational methods has changed the scientific method and how we
    • Data drives challenges to how we store, collect, and analyze data. 
    • Research is now encoded in software, making Software a 1st class object in reproducibility
    • Conclusion: We have well defined methods of proof, we a structured way of detailing how we conduct experiments, we need to have comparable standards for computation and statistical pieces.
    • There are numbers of tools that are being developed to help bring this to light and allow academics to each other’s computation to enable reproducibility.
    • Intellectual property rights: balancing open science with intellectual property.
  2. Statistical:
  •     False discovery, low power, and experimental design issues, and poor methods

There is a failure in or traditional reporting methods, and we haven't evolved with computation.  The coding and scaling of the data is not being done as standard practice.

If we require power calculation and disclosure of negative results with computation we could remove 80% of research that is irreproducible.  With Code and data disclosure

Bench-marking and testing: we don't have a sense of this.


Whose responsibility is this? large organizations, academic boards, private firms.

Dream applications of this:

  • Gain complete access to ALL studies on a particular study
  • Removing the white noise or studies that don't fit our new standard of inquiry
Automatic Tags: data transparency; meta-research; open science; Stanford University

Author: UCMercedLibrary
Title: University of California Libraries: Research Data Matters
Abstract Note: What is research data and why is managing your data important? Where can you get help with research data management? In this introductory video, three University of California researchers address these questions from their own experience and explain the impact of good data management practices. ~~~~~~~~~~~ This has been a project of the Data Curation Common Knowledge Group of the University of California Libraries.  Project Leads Katherine Koziar, UC Riverside (katherine.koziar@ucr.edu) Emily Lin, UCM (elin@ucmerced.edu) Christine Borgman Interview and Footage Tony Aponte, UCLA Greg Barnes, UCLA Office of Instructional Development Sean Cruser, UCLA Katherine Koziar, UC Riverside Bethany Myers, UCLA Rick Prelinger Interview Christy Caldwell, UC Santa Cruz Christy Hightower, UC Santa Cruz Ann Hubble, UC Santa Cruz John Raedeke, UC Santa Cruz Marjorie Zatz Interview Emily Lin, UC Merced UC Merced Communications Video Production Team Video Production: UC Merced Communications Andrew Coughlin, UC Merced Jürgen Gottschalk, UC Merced Emery Silbermann, UC Merced Music Credits Copyright owned by PremiumBeat, Quebec, Canada and used under license to the Regents of the University of California. Unless otherwise indicated, the copyright for this content is held by the Regents of the University of California. 2016.
Notes:
Key Lesson: Academics need to make data and publications in a form that is accessible to the general public and also digestible to all to use.

Our entire living environment is data.  It's up to us to decide what we want to use in our data.

Data Management:

  • Understanding that we don’t own the data b/c of the stakeholders who invest in our research
  • Thus we need to make it useable by those who are invested in this data
    • Other academics but more importantly the public
    • We need to build management structure that allow us to sustain this data over time

The challenges:

  • We lose pieces of data because of poor data hygiene.
  • Academics fail to make data in a format that the public can digest data
  • The library (@ University of California) is taking steps to make data and publications part of the public good.
Automatic Tags: data management; grant funded research; research credibility; research data; research data management; University of California Libraries

Author: Wenglinsky, Harold
Title: Using Technology Wisely: The keys to Success in Schools (2005)
Notes:
Pages 12 - 33:

 Three educational movements emerged in the 1990s:

  1. Standards movement
    • Why: students needed to be held to a higher academic standard
  2. technology movement
    • technology could be a crucial tool in helping students meet these higher standards
  3. improving teacher quality movement
    •    standards needed to be raised for teachers if they were going to berasied for students.

Part of the interconnection between these movements was a need to train teachers in various petagogies in order for them to enact them wi/ the new technologies that were being introduced to the classroom.

The movements struggled due to vagueness of how to approach implementation.  Politics determined whether individual state made standards didactic or constructivist.

Evidence points to having all three movements connecting and operating under constructivist context is key.

    Ex. Teachers should teach a complex problem and give students multiple ways to solve; rather than teaching many problems and one way to solve.  Force students to find proof that they're right rather than give them answers.

(late 90s - 2000s) As this continues politics got involved and from every level.  Govenors investing resources and convening.  At the national level nothing was accomplished b/c fear of a "national curriculum" being imposed by the federal government.

Alot of money moved around during the 90s - themes of improvement:

  • telecom/ internet access in Tier one and poor schools
  • teaching teachers and students how to use tech
  • integrated tech into curriculum

Result:

  • Some improvement although a large number of poor schools didn't receive enough funding to make major changes needed.
  • Teachers 4 - 10 still didn't understand the technology, even more didn't know how to integrate into lessons
  • Private Cos.  also invested in schools at various levels; ultimately pushing for skill development in the classroom

The ultimate issue being that teacher quality and understanding of curiculum didn't improve with the rest so it hasn't worked.

Title: Guide to Social Science Data Preparation and Archiving, Phase 5: Preparing Data for Sharing
Notes:
The importance of thinking through the data before releasing it to the public sense we can not monitor use to ensure that the other researcher respects the confidentiality of the respondent.

 

Thus it is common to prepare public use datasets to alter the files to allow for research but project identity.

 

Our principles of disclosure risk limitation commit us to the idea that information recorded of a individual, group, org or entity should be protected. 

the Fed Depart. Health and Human Services protect all human subjects

Institutional Review Board validated research of human subjects.

Variables that in social science have endangered confidentiality:

Direct identifiers: SSN, Name, phone #

Indirect identifiers: zip code + race, state, county, graduation year and major

Geographic Identifiers: census block, area code

How to treat these (clean the data):

  1. removal
  2. Top-coding: restricting the upper range 0f variables
  3. collapse/ combining variables to make a new variable all together
  4. Sampling: releasing a random sample of sufficient size to yield inference
  5. Swapping: matching unique cases on the indirect identifier, then exchanging the values of key variables between the cases. This retains the analytic utility and covariate structure of the dataset while protecting subject confidentiality. 
  6. Disturbing: dding random variation or stochastic error to the variable. This retains the statistical properties between the variable and its covariates, while preventing someone from using the variable as a means for linking records.

Author: Dharma Akmon • Ann Zimmerman •; Morgan Daniels • Margaret Hedstrom
Title: The application of archival concepts to a data-intensive environment: working with scientists to understand data management and preservation needs. Archival Science
Notes:
Key: Understanding data management from the lens of a scientist as a Archivist.

Abstract: Data Archivist - Scientist lack the skills to properly curate their research data.  Thus Sig. opportunity for archivists and archival scholars but they must first understand the scientific context.

E-science is the law of the land and this requires scientist to not only share scholarly journals but all of the data they collect must be curated for use by others.

Requiring some type of international standard for metadata storage and use.

Challenges:

  1. Little incentive for scientist to share their work science they are rewarded based on manuscript publication.
  2. There is a major lack of common integration data infrastructure.
  3. The issue of lack of standardization is most prevalent in "small sciences"
  4. Head's of labs, "those who need the data the most" feel uncomfortable imposing data standards, and have no authority/ time to enforce them;  NOT TO MENTION - lacking the training to instill best practices.
  5. Scientist do have their own individual systems - disrupting them would have a sig. impact on labs.

Background: Archivists traditionally managed scientific information for a historical context, not the science data.  All data was not deemed useful and any older data that was potentially useful was thought to be managed by the scientist them self, specific to their field of interest and rarely disiminated across fields.

Ex. Challenges:

  • Head scientist struggled with being able to depend on the data collected from the rotating cast of doctoral students.
  • Data collections was "ad hoc"
  • Could not compare previous experiments for a decade ago with current recreations
  • illegibility of paper records
  • Assuming intelligent people would already have data management practices, but everyone "manages" data their own way which inheritly makes it difficult to use by others w/o personal interaction.
  • That data system they tried in past did not stick for multiple reasons:
    • not widely adopted
    • there was only one PC to use to upload (not highly accessible)
    • had to copy your information in two places (notebook and database)
    • lengthy process
Manual Tags: Data curation; Data documentation; Data Management; Data reuse; Science Data

Author: Clarke-Midura, Jody; Dede, Chris
Title: Assessment, Technology, and Change
Publication Title: Journal of Research on Technology in Education
Abstract Note: Despite three decades of advances in information and communications technology (ICT) and a generation of research on cognition and new pedagogical strategies, the field of assessment has not progressed much beyond paper-and pencil item-based tests. Research has shown these instruments are not valid measures of sophisticated intellectual performances. Simply using technology to deliver automated versions of item-based tests does not realize the full power of ICT to innovate in assessment via providing rich experiences that enable observing and analyzing student performances. To illustrate this approach, we describe our early research on using immersive technologies to develop virtual performance assessments.
Journal Abbreviation: Journal of Research on Technology in Education

Author: Kaplan, Diane E.
Title: The Stanley Milgram Papers: A Case Study on Appraisal of and Access to Confidential Data Files
Abstract Note: Decisions regarding the appraisal of confidential records, as well as the establishment of access policies for researchers, are difficult questions that archives must occasionally confront. In such situations, it is necessary to balance the confidentiality and privacy rights of the subjects of the records with the needs of serious researchers. This case study describes one institution's attempt to appraise the confidential data files from a landmark experiment in social psychology. The article further considers ways to protect the privacy of the experiment's subjects while still making the information in the data files available for research.
Notes:
The idea that socielogical experiments are not permissable if they violate human rights or cause harm. 

main points:

  1. Archivist needed to determine how much of Milgrams raw data to maintain if any or to just hold on to the final study. The conflict being that maintaining these records was expensive for the resources they were given to do so.
  2. When this experiment was conducted there weren't rules about protecting privacy, thus is the university in the future responsible for maintaining that right. 
  3. Yale decided to restrict access to these files for 75 years.
  4. Researchers can access the files if they will pay to have them sanitized

If a subject's rights are violated the subject has the right to sue.

in this process we're losing privacy

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 6.1 Learning Curves
Notes:
Visualization: Learning Curves

  • Show data
  • Reveal data a several levels
  • Encourage the eye to compare different data

Important Viz in Edu.

  • The learning curve:
    •    Assumptions:
      • student is practicing the same skill several times in the same fashion (rope learning)
      • Knowledge recall
      • Measuring students speed and accuracy
    • Characteristic:
      • performance (speed and accuracy) improve with a power function
      • Radical improvement at first followed by a flatting
      • Fosbury Flop (High Jump tech)
    • Real - World Data:
      • rarely perfectly smooth
    • Inference:
      • Visual inspection of the curve form
        • seeing how a student is learning if at all
        • understanding if its a compressed scale
        • Seeing if a student is learning an new skill or not
    • Use:
      • Studying whole curic not so much individual students
      • University of Pitt is doing some good work.

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 6.3 Scatter Plots
Notes:
Scatter plots:

  • Problem: they don't scale across "big data" they're better at "little data"
  • Or the oppose is also an issue - it could be too granular for a scatter plot

Heat Map:

  • Better for large scale data
  • Box size is important
  • They can be used for intensity and density

Parameter Space Maps:

  • A special type of heat map
  • They can show how often across a proportion of skills will be the best.

Average Graph:

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 6.4 State Space Diagrams
Notes:
State Space Diagrams:

  • State = a complete characterization of the situations
  • Also known = student learning pathways

State Space Diagram "Refractions" (example) -> Game

  • Can show how a student or groups go through a process or fail to go through a process.
  • Groups: you can see a "logic" path
    • How common a people take particular pathways.
  • Use:
    • Study specific student trajectories
    • study productive paths
    • study rare but productive paths
    • Make recommendations to students based on their path (Hints)

Author: Hew, Khe; Brush, Thomas
Title: Integrating technology into K-12 teaching and learning: current knowledge gaps and recommendations for future research
Abstract Note: Although research studies in education show that use of technology can help student learning, its use is generally affected by certain barriers. In this paper, we first identify the general barriers typically faced by K-12 schools, both in the United States as well as other countries, when integrating technology into the curriculum for instructional purposes, namely: (a) resources, (b) institution, (c) subject culture, (d) attitudes and beliefs, (e) knowledge and skills, and (f) assessment. We then describe the strategies to overcome such barriers: (a) having a shared vision and technology integration plan, (b) overcoming the scarcity of resources, (c) changing attitudes and beliefs, (d) conducting professional development, and (e) reconsidering assessments. Finally, we identify several current knowledge gaps pertaining to the barriers and strategies of technology integration, and offer pertinent recommendations for future research.
Short Title: Integrating technology into K-12 teaching and learning
Notes:
The barriers and solutions to technology integration in K -12.

6 Major barriers to Technology Integration:

  • Resources
    • technology itself
    • access
    • time
    • technical support
  • Knowledge and skills
    • tech related skills
    • tech management skills
    • pedagogy as it relates to tech
      • replacement of old techniques
      • amplification of learning
      • transformation and innovating learning
  • Institutions
    • Leadership buy-in
    • school time-table structure (inflexibility)
    • school planning on how to use Tech
  • Attitudes and beliefs
    • Teachers attitude
  • assessment
    • teachers are pressured to get high grades will lead them to avoid "wasting time" w/ new technology integration. 
  • subject culture
    • the general set of practices that have grown up around particular subjects taht shape the subject and lead to low tech use

Strategy to overcome:

  • Having a shared vision and tech integration plan
    • overcome leadership barrier
    • how to use, goals, guides
    • enhance student learning of curriculum
  • overcoming the scarcity of resources
    • cheaper hardware
    • laptop sand wireless networks over desktops & labs
    • lack of tech support -> teach students how to do simple troubleshooting
  • change attitudes and beliefs
    • principals support throughout
    • relaxed environment for learning tech
  • conducting professional devel.
  • reconsidering assessments

Title: DDI - Data Documentation Initiative | Digital Curation Centre
Manual Tags: Data Documentation Initiative; DDI; Documentation; meta data

Title: How to Appraise and Select Research Data for Curation | Digital Curation Centre
Notes:
Return to this doc to look at all the guidelines...

Purpose: Help me develop an approach to appraising and selecting data sets for curation. 

Reasons why we don't just store all data-sets ever made:

  1. Digital content expands - as the per byte keeps pace with declining cost of storage the real cost of keeping it remains the same or goes up.
  2. Storage cost go up because of mirroring and backup systems.
  3. Discovery.  Keeping everything clutters the search process, making targeted searches more difficult.
  4. Managing and preserving is expensive.  Wasted money on metadata that doesn't matter.

Appraisal Def I like:  (UK) the process of distinguished records of continuing value from those of no further value so that the latter may be eliminated.

  • this is guided by local and community policies and legal requirements. 
  • Must be transparent and accountable.
  • Not based on individual views or possible future research needs.

The Research Councils UK General Rules:

  • Make relevant primary data and research evidence accessible to others for reasonable periods after the completion of the research:
    • normally 10 year period
    • Major clinical or social, environmental 20 yr
  • Manage data according to research funder's data policy
  • When possible, deposit permanently w/in national collection

Author: FitzGerald, Elizabeth; Kucirkova, Natalia
Title: Zuckerberg is ploughing billions into 'personalised learning' – why?
Abstract Note: Zuckerburg wants to plough billions into personalised learning, but his way may not be the right way.
Notes:
Key: What is personalized learning?  How to do we marry edu technology that customize by interest , balancing the needs of teachers, and providing a broad enough lens for students?

Education has become one of 4 areas where the Zuckerbergs have invested $45 billion in w/ their "Chan Zuckerberg Initiatve".

What is Personalized learning:

  • Education scholars
    • modifying learning materials
    • modifying teaching styles
  • Others:
    • "individual learning"
    • learner-centered
  • Zuckerbergs:
    • teachers working w/ students on custom instruction
      • meeting individual needs  & interest
    • human work replaced by tech
    • Algorithms provide users w/ content based on an analysis of behavior & interest
    • similar to how Facebook's newsfeed works

The dangers:

  1. Students over specializing in the content they like at a young age
  2. Real life doesn't accommodate lack of ability or interest
  3. children preferences are not fixed. highly fluid
  4. Children data privacy

Benefits:

  1. motivation to learn
    1. Ex: AltSchool = micro-schools w/ personalized learning

Other orgs are compromising, w/ hybrid: Smart Sparrow or Pearson

  • adapting to learners pace
  • providing course modified based on teachers knowledge of student

Author: Cai, Li; Zhu, Yangyong
Title: The Challenges of Data Quality and Data Quality Assessment in the Big Data Era
Notes:
Key: Big Data Quality Assessment

  • Summarized reviews of data quality research
  • analyzes the data characteristics of the big data environment; present quality challenges faced
  • formulates a data quality framework hierarchy
    • dimensions
    • quality characteristics
    • quality indexes

New technology has led to exponential growth in data. On top of that, every industry has a data arm. 

MIT's Total Data Quality Management group defines data quality = fitness for use

Challenges of data quality in big data:

  • Features of Big Data
    • Volume - Quantity
    • Velocity - Data being formed at exponential rates
    • Variety - Diversity of data (structured vs. unstructured)
      • this creates a challenge around data integration; sources of data:
        • IoT
        • Internet
        • various industry
        • scientific experimental & observational data
      • Unstructured: documents, video, audio
      • Semi: software packages, spreadsheets, financial records
    • Unstructured: make 80% of total amounts of data
    • Value - Value density is inversely proportional to total data size
      • greater the big data scale the less relatively valuable
  • The challenges of data quality
  • No unified and approved data quality standard abroad

Table 1 Great presentations of the dimensions of data quality

  • Accessibility: data openness
  • Timeliness: Quickness from data generation
  • Authorization: who has the right to the data
  • Credibility: data source, normalization, when was it produced
  • Definition/ Documentation:
  • Accuracy
  • Consistency
  • Integrity
  • Completeness
  • Auditability
  • Fitness
  • Readability
  • Structure

ICPSR offers summer programming around quantitiave methods od social reserach for curating and managing research data for re-use. 

5 day workshop mainly for archivist, librarians, data producers.

full range of life cycle activities: data review and preparation; confidential data management; effective documentation practices; how to create, comply with, and evaluate required data management plans; digital repository requirements and assessment; and running user support and promotional activities for data.

Title: Is the “Data Lake” the Best Architecture to Support Big Data? | EMC
Short Title: Is the “Data Lake” the Best Architecture to Support Big Data?
Notes:
Referencing an article from Forbes 2011...

The difference between a data lake and a data warehouse is that in a data warehouse, the data is pre-categorized at the point of entry, which can dictate how it’s going to be analyzed.

The idea being that the data lake would provide more analytical flexibility in the long term.

Data storage has become cheaper but it not cheap enough to make sense of storing data that is ready to be use instantly, but instead it makes sense to place them in repositories cheaply and make them accessible.

How does governance work w/ Data Lakes:

  • Questions around accountability for data quality
  • How do we have a consistent operations (documentation, prioritizing, resolving, communicated data issues)

Information life-cycle management:

  • assuming storage cost will continue to drop, will this data lake lead to more noise.

Security:

  • If all of the data is stored in the same area how do we ensure that the appropriate layers in security for each type of data (separating customer, products, and sales data).

Struc v. Unstruc

  • links between data lakes and metadata respositories

An Alternative to Data Lake

  • People really care about how data is made availability and fit of use.

A well-constructed metadata repository will allow the enterprise to leap-frog over the data lake and empower the delivery of Data as a Service, Analytics as a Service, advanced analytics, self-service BI, self-service data provisioning and Data Science sandbox provisioning.

Title: Terabyte terror: It takes special databases to lasso the Internet of Things | Ars Technica
Notes:
Relational Database = sensor data.  (IoT)

Sensor data is big data.

Scaling data storage w/o degrading or failure. 

Using these data storage facilities allowed for the collection of real-time analytics, which allows them to automate their technology - cutting certain cost (heating, air, water usage, catching leaks, soil quality)

  • Norstroms thermostat
  • Walgreens lights - 1 mil sensors for 4,000 walgreens.

These scalable databases allow for fast turnaround on solution after finding problems. 

All these sensors gather a ton of data points over time. It is important to get this total info the right place. 

There is no normalizing naming convensions for data sensors. 

the better we get at drinking in data from things like the IoT's broken water pumps, the more rapidly we'll be able to fix the IoT's broken things.

Title: Introduction to Social Network Methods:  Chapter 1: Social Network Data
Notes:
SN data lead us to think differently about how to apply statistics.

Major Emphasis:

  1. The first major emphasis is seeing how actors are embedded in the overall network
  2. Seeing how the whole pattern of individual choices give more holistic patterns.

SN analysis looks at actors and relations vs. conventitional looking at actors and attributes. (NOT SURE OF THE DIFFERENCE)

SN have two main parts Nodes (actors) and edges (relations)

  • the subject or nodes isn't about an individual but samples elements.
    • not john and who are his friends
    • but instead john, his friends, and their friends connection
    • thus SN typically doesn't use "samples' but a large portion of a population.
      • all the classrooms in a school
      • all the words in a text
      • An entire social class

Modality: Understanding that every population is needed in multiple networks a student in a class, a class in a school, etc. 

Two mode network: A data set that contains information about 2 types of social entities (say persons and organ.)

Measuring Sampling ties (Edges)

Methods:

  • full network - max info, but can also be costly and difficult ot execute/ generalize. 
    • taking a census of ties.
    • its difficult to collect every information from all individuals, which is needed.
    • most people have limited number of ties anyway.
  • Snowball - begins with a focal actor(s)
    • actors are asked to name others, then the named are asked to name, until no new actors are listed.
    • good for special populations (business contacts, community elites)
    • limitation:
      • isolated folk are not collected
      • overstating connectiveness of a population
      • Thus it is best to start with the most powerful and well connected and work down. (although you still miss those not connected to the elite)
  • ego-centric -
    • alter connections:
      • asking one actor to list folk and list how those folk may know eachother. (localize network)
      • you can also find trends and cliques within that mini network
    • ego only:

Scales of measurement

  • Understanding how you want to rank relationships. 
    • the presence of a tie or the strength of a tie
    • in doing this "dummy" coding you lose a ton of info
  • Thus you might need to engage in full-rank (but uncommon)

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 7.1 Clustering
Notes:
Structure discovery algorithm.

You don't know what the structure is and that's what your hoping to find, data points that are some how grouped together.

K-means clustering

  1. pick how many clusters
  2. choose random centrods
  3. define initial clusters w/ a voyanod diagram
  4. re-fit the centroids
  5. repeat until convergence - where the centroid is in the center.

  • Best value of k with bic or aic

Title: Big Data in Education 7.6 Knowledge Inference: Q-Matrix Knowledge Structure

Q-Matrix

  • row is a item

We're looking for the best model.

  • Assessing performance of students on each skill

Barnes model:

    • are skills conjunctive - need all the skills
    • or are they compensatory (only need of the skills)

John Stamper

  • smooth the learning curve
    • you want a negative slope for this ideally
    • if you see a random spike, this means that 2 skills are being treated as one. 
  • unexpected error rates
  • Pitts science of learning center has tools
    • applies LFA

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 1.3 Classifiers, Part 1
Notes:
classification algorithm

  • Predicting student behavior based off of actions using
    • software performance
    • survey data
    • test data
  • each label is associated with a number of features
  • These algorithm are useful in specific; education:
    • step regression
      • binary classifications (0,1)
      • conservative
      • not good when interaction common
    • logistical regression
      • predictor variables
      • conservative
      • good for where changes in predictor var. have an impact on probability of predicted variable class
      • not good when interaction common
    • J48/ C4.5 Decision Trees
      • Good for interactions
      • open source
      • uses numerical and categorical
      • relatively conservative
    • JRIP Decision Rues
    • K*Instance-Based Classifiers

Title: Big Data in Education 1.4 Classifiers Part 2

Classification cont...

If, Then rules

    • but you need to have all the data points
    • it can be slow
  • bag stumps
    • conservative
  • Random Forest
    • create a number of trees and fit based off all of them.
  • Neural networks

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 2.2 Diagnostic Metrics Part 1
Notes:
Accuracy is a poor metric for assessment b/c the metrics that are used are weighted differently.

  • Kappa is better
    • kappa can be 1 (perfect agreement) , 0 (agreement is a chance), -1 (inverse)

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 2.3  Diagnostic Metrics Part 2
Notes:
Classifiers

Something with two outcomes and you're hoping to know how good your model is.

ROC curve

You can get

  • true pos
  • false pos
  • true neg
  • false neg

You want things above the dash lines.

  • A prime tells you how good your model is at being correct.

Precision - are you true pos actually true pos.

recall - are you capturing all the TRue pos

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 2.4 Diagnostic Metrics: Correlation
Short Title: Big Data in Education 2.4 Diagnostic Metrics
Notes:
Metrics for regression

  • linear correlation
    • In education .3 is a good correlation is fine. Its relative
    • outliners
    • R-squared - model goodness prediction for linear models
    • Mean Ab deviation - how far is our prediction from what it should have been in absolute value
    • Root means square error - penalizes larger deviations more than small deviations. 

    BiC - Bayesian:

    • good interpretability
    • you can understand the difference between models
    • similar to k-fold cross validation
    • There is not bic formulas for formula modess
  • AiC - Akaikes Information:
    • trade off of goodness of fit and flexibility of fit
      • you want to avoid overfitting

You should never just look for one way to validate your model.

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 2.5 Cross-Validation and Over-Fitting
Notes:
Over-fitting - is fitting to the signal but also the noise.

How to prevent

  • use similar models w/ less variables
  • You can't eliminate overfitting but you can make them less harmful.
  • Ask yourself:
    • does it transfer to new context?
      • use k-fold
        • its quicker
      • use Leave-out -one
        • its more stable
        • avoid issues of how to select folds
  • Cross- val variants
    • flat cross
      • each point has equal chance of being placed into fold
    • Stratified cross
      •    biases fold elections to create equality among variables in fold
      • typically the variable you're trying to predict
  • Student-level:
    • no student data is in two folds
    • allow us to use it for new students not just our generalized sample
  • Other level of validation: Does your model work across...
    • lessons
    • schools
    • deomgraphic
    • software packages

Author: ColumbiaLearn
Title: Big Data in Education 4.2 Bayesian Knowledge Tracing
Notes:
how well a student knows a particular skill at a particular time. Based on 0,1 scoring.

This is not a test but a learning structure. 

Baysesian Two-state learning model with BKT

  • learned or unlearned
  • ASSUMPTION: While this isn't TRUE it is an effective model
  • ASSUMPTION:
    • guessing and getting it right
    • knowing and getting it wrong
  • there is probability of latent skill, learning, and guessing, and slipping.
  • See video for formula...

BKT Issues

  • it only used the first problem thus throwing out ton of info but its the clearest info.
    • there are varience that break this
  • We have to trust that a student getting the right result means you know the skill.
    • Thus be careful with P(g) guess and P(s) slip percentages
    • parameters have to be chosen that best predict performance

Public tools:

  • BNT-SM: bayes net toolkit - student modeling
  • Fitting BKT at Scale
  • BKT-BF: BKT-Brute Force (grid search)

Do not use excel equation solver
